issue.title: Segmentation fault if configured with incompatible BDB
issue.body:
Hello, after updating my nodes with Master they will no longer start (segfault). Duplicating this issue requires building --with-incompatible-bdb so I don't think it is super important. Regardless, Here is the segfault:
```
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
user@computer:~/bitcoin$ valgrind ./src/qt/bitcoin-qt 
...
==32418== 
==32418== 
==32418== Process terminating with default action of signal 11 (SIGSEGV)
==32418==  Access not within mapped region at address 0x0
==32418==    at 0x4C30D22: strlen (in /usr/lib/valgrind/vgpreload_memcheck-amd64-linux.so)
==32418==    by 0x76C3331: __os_strdup (in /usr/lib/libdb_cxx-4.8.so)
==32418==    by 0x76959C3: __env_add_data_dir (in /usr/lib/libdb_cxx-4.8.so)
==32418==    by 0x7695A90: __env_set_data_dir (in /usr/lib/libdb_cxx-4.8.so)
==32418==    by 0x75B0B58: DbEnv::set_data_dir(char const*) (in /usr/lib/libdb_cxx-4.8.so)
==32418==    by 0x51C1B7: CDBEnv::Open(boost::filesystem::path const&) (db.cpp:116)
==32418==    by 0x51ED80: CDB::VerifyEnvironment(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, boost::filesystem::path const&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >&) (db.cpp:272)
==32418==    by 0x49FBB0: VerifyWallets() (init.cpp:230)
==32418==    by 0x2BFA95: AppInitMain(boost::thread_group&, CScheduler&) (init.cpp:1266)
==32418==    by 0x187096: BitcoinCore::initialize() (bitcoin.cpp:303)
==32418==    by 0x6AD6698: QObject::event(QEvent*) (in /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQt5Core.so.5.6.1)
==32418==    by 0x5CE08AB: QApplicationPrivate::notify_helper(QObject*, QEvent*) (in /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libQt5Widgets.so.5.6.1)
==32418==  If you believe this happened as a result of a stack
==32418==  overflow in your program's main thread (unlikely but
==32418==  possible), you can try to increase the size of the
==32418==  main thread stack using the --main-stacksize= flag.
==32418==  The main thread stack size used in this run was 8388608.
==32418== 
==32418== HEAP SUMMARY:
==32418==     in use at exit: 47,372,704 bytes in 44,499 blocks
==32418==   total heap usage: 137,047 allocs, 92,548 frees, 77,215,464 bytes allocated
==32418== 
==32418== LEAK SUMMARY:
==32418==    definitely lost: 2,893 bytes in 6 blocks
==32418==    indirectly lost: 14,328 bytes in 610 blocks
==32418==      possibly lost: 16,868 bytes in 212 blocks
==32418==    still reachable: 47,050,655 bytes in 42,427 blocks
==32418==                       of which reachable via heuristic:
==32418==                         length64           : 6,848 bytes in 77 blocks
==32418==                         newarray           : 3,552 bytes in 40 blocks
==32418==                         multipleinheritance: 1,864 bytes in 4 blocks
==32418==         suppressed: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==32418== Rerun with --leak-check=full to see details of leaked memory
==32418== 
==32418== For counts of detected and suppressed errors, rerun with: -v
==32418== Use --track-origins=yes to see where uninitialised values come from
==32418== ERROR SUMMARY: 3 errors from 3 contexts (suppressed: 0 from 0)
Killed
```

The segfault occurs during startup, the splash screen pops up for a second (if launching the GUI). To replicate, simply build from master (configured with incompatible bdb) and try to launch bitcoin-qt.

rename.from: Segmentation fault if configured with incompatbile BDB
rename.to: Segmentation fault if configured with incompatible BDB

events.body: I tested on an updated Ubuntu (17.10) install and it doesn't segfault at startup anymore. Looks like this segfault effects Ubuntu 16.10 and older using the libdb4.8 4.8.30-yakkety3 package. Not sure what other systems might be effected.

Hmm, error is in datadir parsing. Can you provide the path to -datadir and the full path implied by it?

On December 30, 2017 3:37:32 AM GMT+01:00, CryptAxe <notifications@github.com> wrote:
>I tested on an updated Ubuntu (17.10) install and it doesn't segfault
>at startup anymore. Looks like this segfault effects Ubuntu 16.10 and
>older using the libdb4.8 4.8.30-yakkety3 package. Not sure what other
>systems might be effected.
>
>-- 
>You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
>Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
>https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/12047#issuecomment-354522955

The segfault here looks very similar to the one in #6775.

Someone also posted this on the bitcoin stack-exchange a few weeks ago: https://bitcoin.stackexchange.com/questions/64541/building-bitcoin-segmentation-fault-on-building-wallet-ubuntu

@TheBlueMatt default data directory ```~/.bitcoin```

I also just tried 
``` ./src/qt/bitcoin-qt -datadir=/home/cryptaxe/newDataDir``` 

and got
```
Segmentation fault (core dumped)
```

Heres debug.log from that directory (it did manage to write some log messages before the segfault) if anyone can make sense of it:

```
2017-12-30 02:40:01 Bitcoin version v0.15.99.0-5180a86
2017-12-30 02:40:01 InitParameterInteraction: parameter interaction: -whitelistforcerelay=1 -> setting -whitelistrelay=1
2017-12-30 02:40:01 Assuming ancestors of block 0000000000000000003b9ce759c2a087d52abc4266f8f4ebd6d768b89defa50a have valid signatures.
2017-12-30 02:40:01 Setting nMinimumChainWork=000000000000000000000000000000000000000000723d3581fe1bd55373540a
2017-12-30 02:40:01 Using the 'sse4' SHA256 implementation
2017-12-30 02:40:01 Default data directory /home/cryptaxe/.bitcoin
2017-12-30 02:40:01 Using data directory /home/cryptaxe/newDataDir
2017-12-30 02:40:01 Using config file /home/cryptaxe/newDataDir/bitcoin.conf
2017-12-30 02:40:01 Using at most 125 automatic connections (1024 file descriptors available)
2017-12-30 02:40:01 Using 16 MiB out of 32/2 requested for signature cache, able to store 524288 elements
2017-12-30 02:40:01 Using 16 MiB out of 32/2 requested for script execution cache, able to store 524288 elements
2017-12-30 02:40:01 Using 4 threads for script verification
2017-12-30 02:40:01 scheduler thread start
2017-12-30 02:40:01 Using wallet directory /home/cryptaxe/newDataDir
2017-12-30 02:40:01 init message: Verifying wallet(s)...
2017-12-30 02:40:01 Using BerkeleyDB version Berkeley DB 4.8.30: (April  9, 2010)
2017-12-30 02:40:01 Using wallet wallet.dat
2017-12-30 02:40:01 CDBEnv::Open: LogDir=/home/cryptaxe/newDataDir/database ErrorFile=/home/cryptaxe/newDataDir/db.log
```
@fanquake as with those you have linked to, I have no db.log created either. If that helps anyone.
It's possible that you're linking against a different version of BDB than the header files compiled against. This reeks like an ABI conflict.
Can you pastebin your `config.log` and maybe look for possible multiple BerkleyDB-dev installation interference?

Had the same issue on 16.10. 
I fixed the issue by installing libdb4.8-dev, by default even on 16.10 you get libdb5.3-dev and when you configure with --with-incompatible-bdb you get a segmentation fault.

On 17.10 which you say you're running you don't have 4.8 
https://packages.ubuntu.com/artful/libdb++-dev

You might want to try bitcoin/contrib/install_db4.sh

> This reeks like an ABI conflict.

Looking at the traceback I'm sure this is the case. The gdb error is in `libdb_cxx-4.8.so` while you had to provide `--with-incompatible-bdb` which means that it was detecting 5.x headers.
Removing this from the 0.16.0 milestone as I don't think this should block the release, this has been an issue forever.

If bdb provides a way to get the version number at runtime it might be possible to compare with the version at build time to give a sane error in this case instead of a crash.

I found the reason of this issue, and a solution (a good workaround).

The issue occurs (in my case) with Ubuntu 18.04, when I install both libdb-4.8++ and libdb-5.3++.  I need those 2, because I do compile programs that require both versions (legacy and new programs).

I installed both versions from Ubuntu standard PPA, and you end up with both versions installed (libdb_cxx-4.8.so and libdb-5.3_cxx.so).

Also, and this is an important point, is that you also do get only one header set installed, which are db.h and db_cxx.h for version 5.3.  So, when 'configure' goes through the detection phase, it does detect that the DB_VERSION_MAJOR/DB_VERSION_MINOR is 5.3 (this is from db.h for version 5.3).

So, you have no choice but to use libdb_cxx-5.3.  But here, just specifying --with-incompatible-bdb is not enough when you have both version installed, you MUST ALSO specify BDB_LIBS="-ldb_cxx-5.3" on the configure line.  That is, you must specify

`./configure --with-incompatible-bdb BDB_LIBS="-ldb_cxx-5.3"`

Without that, i.e. when you just specify the incompatible option, and not the BDB_LIBS option, then the 'bitcoin-find-bdb48.m4' autoconf file will just search for 'libdb_cxx-4.8.so', and find that this file exist.  So, it will create Makefiles linking with '-ldb_cxx4.8', but uses include file db_cxx.h which does include the db.h for version 5.3.  So, you end up with 3 things, that is: 5.3 header, 4.8 lib, and a segfault.

Again, this issue is there because I have both 4.8 and 5.3 installed, and the 'bitcoin-find-bdb48.m4' is not able to cope with this case, and use the version from the header file (i.e. detect that 5.3 header is present, and so, use -ldb_cxx-5.3).

By specifying

`./configure --with-incompatible-bdb BDB_LIBS="-ldb_cxx-5.3"`

you end up acknowledging that you use a 'legacy wallet incompatible' BDB (ignore the fact that v5.3 is detected), and ACTUALLY link against 5.3

Eric
